title: What I love about Aggretsuko
body:
It’s a small detail really but something I love about Aggretsuko is that it’s furry cast isn’t the usual stock animals you’d see anywhere else but species that’s a little obscure….at least to the average joe schmo…as an animal lover I appreciate it.

First off you got a Red Panda as a main character (which I always thought was a pretty standard animal but apparently it’s obscure since lots of people call Retsuko a badger or a raccoon…did nobody watch Kung Fu Panda?)

Tsubone is either a monitor lizard, komodo dragon or a gila monster.

In the background cast you got a Maned Wolf, which I don’t think I’ve ever seen in a show outside of Dora.

What looks like a capybara (it could also be a beaver but idk)

And a Pallas Cat!

There’s also Washimi the secretary bird, the mandrill bouncer, and the wombat waiter from the Christmas special.

Also while not exactly obscure you don’t see meerkats, hyenas, or fennec foxes walking around when they could have made them just a fox, a dog(I know hyenas aren’t dogs, but you know what I mean), or a weasel.

(and in the case of dear sweet Haida it’s one of the only truly nice hyenas I think I’ve ever seen in animation).

Also is Tsunoda one of those tiny jungle deers? Wikipedia says she’s a gazelle but she reminds me of a muntjac.

Yeah you still have a pig, a gorilla, a hippo and other stuff like that, but IDK I think I just like the weird subversion of detail and recognition of some seldom-seen species.

summary: The Moonlight Witch’s Top 10 anime of 2018: Part Three
title: The Moonlight Witch’s Top 10 anime of 2018: Part Three
body:
3. Megalobox

Megalobox is a show I was cautiously anticipating before it’s airing. While I’ve largely gotten over my general aversion to sports anime (watch Haikyuu!! guys), I wasn’t sure if that would extend to a sport I find even less appealing than most. However, I gave Megalobox a chance, and I’m glad I did because it ended up easily being one of the best anime of the year.

The first thing that jumps out about Megalobox is its incredible aesthetic. Megalobox is a strikingly good-looking series with incredibly detailed backgrounds and strong, unique character designs that give the show an incredible sense of realism, immersing the viewer in its world. The stark difference between the dull grit of the slums and the sleek elegance of Megalonia does more too show the class divide between these two worlds than any dialogue ever could. The animation is also fantastically dynamic bringing the boxing bouts to life, making them a consistently exciting watch. And the visuals are topped off by an excellent musical score to bring this show to life. Even if it had nothing else, Megalobox could run on sheer aesthetics alone.

Of course, aesthetics aren’t the only thing Megalobox has to offer. Its narrative is a familiar one- the underdog fighter who slowly works his way up the ranks to victory. But just because a story is familiar doesn’t mean it’s bad and Megalobox executes its story with a cool confidence that sucks the viewer in. It’s easy to get invested in this classic underdog story rooted in contrasting social classes, especially in the moments when it dips into surprisingly dark and heavy material- episode 5 is a particular stand-out, focusing on the military past between two characters that left both mentally and physically traumatised making for a deeply harrowing episode.

The characters help a lot too. Main character “gearless” Joe is easy to root for in his desire to make it to the top, and for the audience to worry about given that he’s reckless to the point of self-destruction. His main rival Yuri is also appealing. Rather than a one-dimensional villain, he views Joe as a worthy opponent who he wants to take on head-to-head on fair terms. Perhaps the most developed character is Joe’s trainer Nanbu, whose outer layer of cynicism hides a strong desire to live in a more idealistic world. My personal favourite character was the Megalobox sponsor Yukiko, who initially comes of as a cold professional but as times goes on is shown to have a strong moral centre. Megalobox’s general lack of one-dimensional villains is a particular strength- even those placed in an antagonistic role generally have strong motivations for being who they are.  

Overall Megalobox stands as a show that I wasn’t sure if I should watch or not, but I’m very glad I gave it a chance because it ended up being one of the most thoroughly enjoyable experiences of the year.

2. Aggressive Retsuko

I’m kind of cheating by putting Aggretsuko on this list. Typically I restrict my end of year list purely to tv anime and as an OVA short Aggretsuko kinds of falls outside that category. But if anything this year deserves a spot on my best-of list it’s Aggretsuko which was far and away one of the most enjoyable experiences of the year.  

The first and most noticeable thing about Aggretsuko is how incredibly #relatable it is. There are few other shows that so powerfully capture the feeling of being an exhausted millennial, trying to make it through your daily life dealing with alarm clocks, demanding bosses and overbearing retail employees. It’s a uniquely accurate portrayal of being the average working person in late-stage capitalism, and many people watching might find themselves feeling that the exhausted protagonist’s struggles hit almost too close to home.

It also helps that so many of the characters of the show are both entertaining and appealing, even aside from our relatable protagonist Retsuko. My personal favourite was Retsuko’s friend Fenneko who seems to run on pure spite as a way to deal with the difficulties of adulthood. But adding to the cast are characters such as Kabae the gossipy office lady who may or may not be a corporate spy, too-cheerful Tsunoda who sucks up to the bosses and has an ongoing rivalry with Fenneko and finally the office ladies Washimi and Gori, who on the surface seem to have it all put together but who under the surface may be as big a mess as the rest of the cast. All the characters in the show are remarkably entertaining and a constant treat to watch.  

One particular way this show shines is how is addresses workplace issues that face women specifically. A big part of the show is focused around Retsuko dealing with the harassment she receives from her boss, a literal chauvinist big, and the show’s primary antagonist. It’s a testament to Aggretsuko’s skilled storytelling that it allows the situation to be difficult to solve- a common refrain in these situations is ‘why didn’t she just report it?’ But Aggretsuko shows how difficult that can be to do, and that the threat of retaliation is very real and present and difficult to work around. There are a lot of ways a bad boss can make an employees life hell even while technically not breaking any rules and Aggretsuko understands this implicitly.

A final thing I particularly appreciated about Aggretsuko is its treatment of romantic relationships, which is something I rarely see explored in fiction. As a way of dealing with her workplace struggles, Retsuko throws herself into her first love, believing that the happiness of a relationship will solve all her problems, regardless of the fact that the addition of a romantic relationship will have no effect on her workplace issues or the fact that her new boyfriend is terribly inconsiderate. “Love fixes everything’ is an enduring and deeply misguided common trait in fiction and I enjoyed that Aggretsuko chooses to challenge it. Not just in it’s handling of Retsuko’s romantic relationship, but also with her male friend Haida who has a crush on her and admits that it may blind him to who she is, but that he would like the chance to get to know the real her. It’s an extremely healthy take on romantic relationships and one that I would appreciate seeing more of in fiction.

Aggretsuko wasn’t a show I had eyes on before it aired, but I’m very happy I watched it. It’s a show that just about anyone could enjoy regardless of whether they’re an anime fan or not and one of the most relatable shows of the year. It’s remarkable how much this little show was able to achieve in just 10 short episodes, and I’m very much looking forward to the second season.

1. Planet With

There are a few shows on this list that were unexpected, but Planet With may have been the biggest unexpected surprise of them all. This show went from being completely not on my radar at all to being my absolute best of the year. There have been years where I’ve struggled to pick an unambiguous top show, but 2018 was not one of them. I knew from the minute Planet With finished that it would be tough for any other show to top it and I wasn’t wrong. Planet With stands strong as not just my favourite show of the year but as a strong addition to my favourite shows of all time.

The first thing that grabbed my attention about Planet With was the way it messed with traditional ideas of heroism and villainy. Planet With’s immediate themes and plot are based on the Super Sentai genre of long-running episodic shows with colourfully themed superheroes fighting against evil, and while I don’t have a lot of experience with the Super Sentai genre, I am a long time fan of its female counterpart, magical girl shows. Planet With immediately sets up expectations with a team of heroic fighters coming in to save the day, but they aren’t the main protagonists of the piece- an odd, mysterious team fighting to steal their powers are our real protagonists. I’m always a fan of shows that seek to challenge our ideas of heroes vs villains and good vs evil so Planet With immediately captured my attention on that front. After all, as most audiences know the villains are often the most interesting characters in a show.  

But Planet With doesn’t just stop there. It’s one thing to set up an initial subversion of heroes vs villains, it’s another thing to follow through on that with well-delivered themes and ideas. One of Planet With’s greatest strengths is its complex web of character motivations and goals. No side feels too clearly right or wrong in Planet With, and all have strong motives for what they do outside the narrowly defined lines of “good” and “evil” even if the show ultimately disagrees with their goals. Are optimism and hope right or are they naivety that will lead to destruction? Is it right to impose your will on others if that will present tragedy? Is a species growth worth supporting even if that growth may go in a dangerous direction? Planet With asks many difficult questions from many different points of view. In fact, one of the strongest scenes of the show occurs when two of its antagonists fight and point out the flaws in each other’s ideologies, both of which the show ultimately rejects. It’s fascinating how much meat Planet With is able to get out of what could be a simple clash of good against evil.

Given the richness of its themes it should be no surprise that Planet With’s characters are also rich and engaging. The main character Soya is an amnesiac antihero living with a maid-outfit wearing woman called Ginko and a giant space cat known as Sensei. The three of them form an unlikely and surprisingly touching domesticity, and all three have their own pasts and goals. The side characters are no less appealing- it’s amazing how much characterisation Planet With is able to pact into its relatively large cast given its limited runtime. Each of the Grand Paladin warriors, in particular, gets a moment in the spotlight, and all their stories are legitimately interesting and often tear-inducing. The villains of the piece are also interesting and even likeable in their own right, with sympathetic goals and ideals even when they’re in an antagonistic role.

But perhaps the strongest thing about Planet With is that much of its themes ultimately boil down to the power of joy and empathy to make the universe a better place and to fight fear and authoritarian ideals. Planet With believes earnestly and firmly in the power of positive thinking and in the benefits of compassion and forgiveness. Planet With isn’t a naive show, it acknowledges humanities flaws, but it believes we have the potential to work past them and love one another. In a tumultuous world sometimes empathy for one another can be both the most difficult and most important thing. Or as the show itself says “it is a far greater thing than justice to witness the harshness of the world and still remain kind.”  

Planet With is a show like none other, packing a full 50 episodes worth of story and themes into just 12 episodes. The show made me tear up more than once, and by the time it was over I felt both fully satisfied and desperate to experience it all over again. It’s a deeply underrated show that I’m sure many people this year missed out on- and if you’re one of those people give it a shot. It’s undeniably the most worthwhile show of the year.

(part one) (part two)

It’s remarkable how much this little show was able to achieve in just 10 short episodes, and I’m very much looking forward to the second season.

1. Planet With

There are a few shows on this list that were unexpected, but Planet With may have been the biggest unexpected surprise of them all. This show went from being completely not on my radar at all to being my absolute best of the year. There have been years where I’ve struggled to pick an unambiguous top show, but 2018 was not one of them. I knew from the minute Planet With finished that it would be tough for any other show to top it and I wasn’t wrong. Planet With stands strong as not just my favourite show of the year but as a strong addition to my favourite shows of all time.

The first thing that grabbed my attention about Planet With was the way it messed with traditional ideas of heroism and villainy. Planet With’s immediate themes and plot are based on the Super Sentai genre of long-running episodic shows with colourfully themed superheroes fighting against evil, and while I don’t have a lot of experience with the Super Sentai genre, I am a long time fan of its female counterpart, magical girl shows. Planet With immediately sets up expectations with a team of heroic fighters coming in to save the day, but they aren’t the main protagonists of the piece- an odd, mysterious team fighting to steal their powers are our real protagonists. I’m always a fan of shows that seek to challenge our ideas of heroes vs villains and good vs evil so Planet With immediately captured my attention on that front. After all, as most audiences know the villains are often the most interesting characters in a show.  

But Planet With doesn’t just stop there. It’s one thing to set up an initial subversion of heroes vs villains, it’s another thing to follow through on that with well-delivered themes and ideas. One of Planet With’s greatest strengths is its complex web of character motivations and goals. No side feels too clearly right or wrong in Planet With, and all have strong motives for what they do outside the narrowly defined lines of “good” and “evil” even if the show ultimately disagrees with their goals. Are optimism and hope right or are they naivety that will lead to destruction? Is it right to impose your will on others if that will present tragedy? Is a species growth worth supporting even if that growth may go in a dangerous direction? Planet With asks many difficult questions from many different points of view. In fact, one of the strongest scenes of the show occurs when two of its antagonists fight and point out the flaws in each other’s ideologies, both of which the show ultimately rejects. It’s fascinating how much meat Planet With is able to get out of what could be a simple clash of good against evil.

Given the richness of its themes it should be no surprise that Planet With’s characters are also rich and engaging. The main character Soya is an amnesiac antihero living with a maid-outfit wearing woman called Ginko and a giant space cat known as Sensei. The three of them form an unlikely and surprisingly touching domesticity, and all three have their own pasts and goals. The side characters are no less appealing- it’s amazing how much characterisation Planet With is able to pact into its relatively large cast given its limited runtime. Each of the Grand Paladin warriors, in particular, gets a moment in the spotlight, and all their stories are legitimately interesting and often tear-inducing. The villains of the piece are also interesting and even likeable in their own right, with sympathetic goals and ideals even when they’re in an antagonistic role.

But perhaps the strongest thing about Planet With is that much of its themes ultimately boil down to the power of joy and empathy to make the universe a better place and to fight fear and authoritarian ideals. Planet With believes earnestly and firmly in the power of positive thinking and in the benefits of compassion and forgiveness. Planet With isn’t a naive show, it acknowledges humanities flaws, but it believes we have the potential to work past them and love one another. In a tumultuous world sometimes empathy for one another can be both the most difficult and most important thing. Or as the show itself says “it is a far greater thing than justice to witness the harshness of the world and still remain kind.”  

Planet With is a show like none other, packing a full 50 episodes worth of story and themes into just 12 episodes. The show made me tear up more than once, and by the time it was over I felt both fully satisfied and desperate to experience it all over again. It’s a deeply underrated show that I’m sure many people this year missed out on- and if you’re one of those people give it a shot. It’s undeniably the most worthwhile show of the year.

trail.content_raw:
3. Megalobox

Megalobox is a show I was cautiously anticipating before it’s airing. While I’ve largely gotten over my general aversion to sports anime (watch Haikyuu!! guys), I wasn’t sure if that would extend to a sport I find even less appealing than most. However, I gave Megalobox a chance, and I’m glad I did because it ended up easily being one of the best anime of the year.

The first thing that jumps out about Megalobox is its incredible aesthetic. Megalobox is a strikingly good-looking series with incredibly detailed backgrounds and strong, unique character designs that give the show an incredible sense of realism, immersing the viewer in its world. The stark difference between the dull grit of the slums and the sleek elegance of Megalonia does more too show the class divide between these two worlds than any dialogue ever could. The animation is also fantastically dynamic bringing the boxing bouts to life, making them a consistently exciting watch. And the visuals are topped off by an excellent musical score to bring this show to life. Even if it had nothing else, Megalobox could run on sheer aesthetics alone.

Of course, aesthetics aren’t the only thing Megalobox has to offer. Its narrative is a familiar one- the underdog fighter who slowly works his way up the ranks to victory. But just because a story is familiar doesn’t mean it’s bad and Megalobox executes its story with a cool confidence that sucks the viewer in. It’s easy to get invested in this classic underdog story rooted in contrasting social classes, especially in the moments when it dips into surprisingly dark and heavy material- episode 5 is a particular stand-out, focusing on the military past between two characters that left both mentally and physically traumatised making for a deeply harrowing episode.

The characters help a lot too. Main character “gearless” Joe is easy to root for in his desire to make it to the top, and for the audience to worry about given that he’s reckless to the point of self-destruction. His main rival Yuri is also appealing. Rather than a one-dimensional villain, he views Joe as a worthy opponent who he wants to take on head-to-head on fair terms. Perhaps the most developed character is Joe’s trainer Nanbu, whose outer layer of cynicism hides a strong desire to live in a more idealistic world. My personal favourite character was the Megalobox sponsor Yukiko, who initially comes of as a cold professional but as times goes on is shown to have a strong moral centre. Megalobox’s general lack of one-dimensional villains is a particular strength- even those placed in an antagonistic role generally have strong motivations for being who they are.  

Overall Megalobox stands as a show that I wasn’t sure if I should watch or not, but I’m very glad I gave it a chance because it ended up being one of the most thoroughly enjoyable experiences of the year.

2. Aggressive Retsuko

I’m kind of cheating by putting Aggretsuko on this list. Typically I restrict my end of year list purely to tv anime and as an OVA short Aggretsuko kinds of falls outside that category. But if anything this year deserves a spot on my best-of list it’s Aggretsuko which was far and away one of the most enjoyable experiences of the year.  

The first and most noticeable thing about Aggretsuko is how incredibly #relatable it is. There are few other shows that so powerfully capture the feeling of being an exhausted millennial, trying to make it through your daily life dealing with alarm clocks, demanding bosses and overbearing retail employees. It’s a uniquely accurate portrayal of being the average working person in late-stage capitalism, and many people watching might find themselves feeling that the exhausted protagonist’s struggles hit almost too close to home.

It also helps that so many of the characters of the show are both entertaining and appealing, even aside from our relatable protagonist Retsuko. My personal favourite was Retsuko’s friend Fenneko who seems to run on pure spite as a way to deal with the difficulties of adulthood. But adding to the cast are characters such as Kabae the gossipy office lady who may or may not be a corporate spy, too-cheerful Tsunoda who sucks up to the bosses and has an ongoing rivalry with Fenneko and finally the office ladies Washimi and Gori, who on the surface seem to have it all put together but who under the surface may be as big a mess as the rest of the cast. All the characters in the show are remarkably entertaining and a constant treat to watch.  

One particular way this show shines is how is addresses workplace issues that face women specifically. A big part of the show is focused around Retsuko dealing with the harassment she receives from her boss, a literal chauvinist big, and the show’s primary antagonist. It’s a testament to Aggretsuko’s skilled storytelling that it allows the situation to be difficult to solve- a common refrain in these situations is ‘why didn’t she just report it?’ But Aggretsuko shows how difficult that can be to do, and that the threat of retaliation is very real and present and difficult to work around. There are a lot of ways a bad boss can make an employees life hell even while technically not breaking any rules and Aggretsuko understands this implicitly.

A final thing I particularly appreciated about Aggretsuko is its treatment of romantic relationships, which is something I rarely see explored in fiction. As a way of dealing with her workplace struggles, Retsuko throws herself into her first love, believing that the happiness of a relationship will solve all her problems, regardless of the fact that the addition of a romantic relationship will have no effect on her workplace issues or the fact that her new boyfriend is terribly inconsiderate. “Love fixes everything’ is an enduring and deeply misguided common trait in fiction and I enjoyed that Aggretsuko chooses to challenge it. Not just in it’s handling of Retsuko’s romantic relationship, but also with her male friend Haida who has a crush on her and admits that it may blind him to who she is, but that he would like the chance to get to know the real her. It’s an extremely healthy take on romantic relationships and one that I would appreciate seeing more of in fiction.

Aggretsuko wasn’t a show I had eyes on before it aired, but I’m very happy I watched it. It’s a show that just about anyone could enjoy regardless of whether they’re an anime fan or not and one of the most relatable shows of the year. It’s remarkable how much this little show was able to achieve in just 10 short episodes, and I’m very much looking forward to the second season.

title: Pretty-Rage & Kamen Haida: Part 1
body:
Narrator: Tokyo. A bustling metropolis for the modern age. A prime target for the imperialistic forces of the Byriam Empire, whose goal is to conquer, or destroy, every single being on Earth. But not to fear! For within these city walls lie two of the greatest heroes of our generation! Both are seemingly normal accountants in a boring day job. But secretly, they are the magical red panda of love, Pretty-Rage, and the hyena hero of justice, Kamen Haida! Together, both in battle, and in matrimony, they swore to keep the city safe, and the Byriams at bay. Here they are now, walking with their trusted friend, and tech associate, Fenneko, and their precious son, Ikari, talking about protecting the Earth, no doubt!

Retsuko: Agh, I can’t believe I forgot to pack myself a lunch today! I skipped breakfast too!

Haida: Retsuko, it’s alright! We’ll just quickly walk by some place, and get something for you to eat.

Fenneko: No can do. We’re crunched for time, Ton’s got a lot of work for us.

Haida: …who told y-Tsunoda?

Fenneko: Tsunoda.

Haida: Figured.

Retsuko: Well, there’s a convenience store coming up, you sure we can’t ju-*noticing a fight breaking out in front of the store*

Haida: …come on! *the two run towards the two men fighting*

Customer: *pinning the store clerk to the ground* You son of a bitch! You gonna rob your customers too?!

Store Clerk: I-I’m so sorry! I don’t understand it, myself!

Haida: *pulling the customer back* Hey, HEY! Cool it!

Retsuko: *gets the store clerk back up* What’s going on, here?!

Customer: People are starving out here, that’s what!

Haida: …huh?

Fenneko: *looking inside the store* Uh, guys? I think you might wanna see this.

*they look inside, and see all the food in the convenience store is gone! Not a single morsel left!*

Retsuko: ….what?!

Customer: It’s not just here! The whole town is out of food! Restaurants, lunch rooms, everywhere! I don’t know what kinda strike, or prank this is, but I won’t stand for it! *storms away*

Haida: What the hell…?

Today’s episode: Retsuko’s Starvation! The Gluttonous Monster Attacks!

*later at work…*

Retsuko: *stomach starts growling badly* Why today? WHY?

Fenneko: You know, you give yourself crap for this, but actually, I was gonna make myself something for breakfast, but I couldn’t find anything in my place.

Haida: ….come to think of it, I didn’t see anything in our place too! I know we’re not the richest, but we CAN’T be that broke.

Ton: *distant* WHERE IS MY TEA?!

Tsubone: THERE WAS NONE MADE! WE CHECKED!

Ton: WHAT?! Ugh, *stomping over to check* as if the women in here aren’t lazy enough already! ….wait, where is everything?!

*the other employees begin running towards the tearoom, to discover, like was revealed earlier, there is no consumable object in sight*

Haida: …oh, I hoped that was just an exaggeration.

Fenneko: Okay, something is going on. Come on. *she grabs out her laptop, and places it on the lunch table the three usually sit*

Retsuko: You think it’s the Byriam?

Fenneko: “Think?” Retsuko, I know. We just gotta figure it out. Lucky me, I happened to hack into all the major security cameras in Tokyo.

Haida: ….why?

Fenneko: The less you know, the better. Anyway, it’s apparently been going on all morning, so let’s see if we can figure out what happened last night. *opens up software, to reveal, indeed, security footage spread all across the city* And it looks like the cannibals are out and about this lovely day.

Retsuko: *seeing people attack one another* Good grief…

Fenneko: Anyhoo! Let’s see if we can turn back time a wee bit. *starts rewinding footage, to last night, early in the morning* Now, let’s take a looksie at the convenience store we checked out. *finds the cameras for the store, and checks out the footage*

*at around 2:00 AM, the back door flies open, and suddenly a ton of food starts floating out, into the sky…*

Fenneko: …what the fu-

Haida: Look! *he sees other cameras, showing food from all across Tokyo, floating off, in a similar way* What’s going on?!

Fenneko: Actually, look. It’s not all going to the sky, looks like it’s going to that forest over there.

Retsuko: …isn’t that Koajiro Forest?

Haida: …we should probably check it out.

Retsuko: Let’s go! *the two almost take off, before her dress is tugged by something* Huh?

Ikari: Mamaaaa! *whines a little, as an audible growl can come from his stomach*

Retsuko: Aw, Ikari! *pats his head* We’ll get you something to eat soon. Okay, sweetums? *to Fenneko* Can you get him, like, some water, or something, to hold him over?

Fenneko: I can try.

Retsuko: Thanks. *to Haida* Come on!

*the two begin to run off, as the rest of the office is trying to find something resembling food*

Ton: Any luck?!

Komiya: N-no, sir!

Ton: WELL, KEEP LOOKING!

*outside, just on the side of the office building, Retsuko and Haida stand*

Retsuko: *grabbing out a pink microphone, with a heart on top* Ready?

Haida: *revealing his golden belt, with a switch on it* Ready!

*Retsuko twirls the heart on the microphone, and Haida flicks the switch on the belt buckle, as the two do some poses, before shouting out…*

Retsuko and Haida: HENSHIN!

*and with that, they transform, into the adorable, but angry, Pretty-Rage, and the tall, and deadly, Kamen Haida, complete with a motorcycle!*

Kamen Haida: *mounts the motorcycle* Hop on!

Pretty-Rage: *mounts behind him* Let’s figure this out!

Kamen Haida: Right! *drives off, as they head out to Koajiro Forest…*

*meanwhile, in said forest, a gigantic pile of food has been accumulated, by various Byriam foot soldiers (named Cronions), and monitored by two monsters, one being a creature resembling a Kabuki actor, except being considerably obese, named Kuishinbō, and the other being a burnt-red, slim, demonic bird looking being, named Phoenixia*

Kuishinbō: Ohohohohoho! Oh, joyous of days! So much food, ripe for the taking!

Phoenixia: Yes, but this is just the beginning. With all of this, the Earthlings’ energy and morale will be dwindling considerably, giving the empire the perfect time to strike….obviously not the primary concern for you, I imagine.

Kuishinbō: Not at all! *charges at the food pile, and begins chowing down*

*while all this is going down, Pretty-Rage and Kamen Haida are hiding in the bushes, seeing all of this going down*

Kamen Haida: So that’s where it all went.

Pretty-Rage: *getting irritated at the monster eating the food* That bastard…come on! Let’s get them!

Kamen Haida: Right! *the two jump up, causing the Cronions to look around*

Phoenixia: Agh, damn it! They’re here! Get into formation!

*the Cronions prepare themselves, as the two heroes land*

Pretty-Rage: Using my death metal anger to make this a world of happiness! PRETTY-RAGE!

Kamen Haida: A punk at heart trying to bring order to this land! KAMEN HAIDA!

Phoenixia: *sigh* So it appears we meet again.

Pretty-Rage: It appears so, Phoenixia! That food belongs to the civilians of Tokyo! Give it back, now!

Kuishinbō: *jumping up and down* Noooooo! They want to take away my snacks! Cronions! ATTACK!

Cronions: *high pitched squeaks, as they charge towards the two!*

Pretty-Rage: Let’s do this! *jumps up, and screams, causing some Cronions to fall back!*

Kamen Haida: Let’s go! *grabs one goon, and punches it right in the gut, before throwing it aside!*

Phoenixia: Agh! FIRE!

Cronion: *nods, as a few of them grab out uzis, and begin firing at the two heroes!*

Kamen Haida: YIPE! *he and Pretty-Rage jump away from the blast, but when they do, he notices her…squirming* …are you okay?

Pretty-Rage: *clenching her stomach* I-I’m fine! Come on! *runs after the monster*

Kuishinbō: Ohohoho! Feeling a touch weak, are we? Well, maybe this oughta make you feel worse! *grabs out a sword from his side, and slashes her multiple times, causing her to fly back!*

Pretty-Rage: AAAGH! *falls to the ground, unconscious*

Kamen Haida: PRETTY-RAGE! *runs to her, and looks at Kuishinbō* Bastard!

Kuishinbō: Yooooooo!!! *laughs maniacally* I got one! I got one!

Kamen Haida: Ugh! *charges at the monster, and tries to perform a jump-kick*

Kuishinbō: Ohohoho! *grabs Kamen Haida’s foot, and begins swinging him around*

Kamen Haida: What the-?! *gets sent flying to the ground* GAAH! *hits the dirt, next to his knocked-out comrade* Dammit, we’re not up to full strength! I gotta get you out of here! *picks her up* This is not the end! *runs off*

Phoenixia: Oh, it will be. *to some of the Cronion soldiers* YOU! Go after them!

Kamen Haida: *reaching the motorcycle, and drives off, Pretty-Rage carried on his back* Come on, Retsuko, stay with me here! I’ll find some food for you! Someho-*he suddenly hears gunshots* GAH! WHAT THE-?! *he turns, and sees Cronion soldiers, on motorcycles, firing at them* No, NO! *he sees an exit, and immediately makes the turn*

Cronion: *high-pitched scream, as they TRY to make the turn, but crash*

Kamen Haida: Okay…don’t worry, Retsuko. We’ll get you feeling better…*starts feeling dizzy* …no….no, not now…damn it, now I’m getting hungry…and thirsty….and….tired…*suddenly crashes the bike, leaving the two rolling on the ground on the ground, unconscious*

So, um…as you can see, it’s quite the biggun. :P Yeah, I really wanted this to be one big thing, but I wanted to get something out to you guys, so that there’s something to tide everyone over. And as it turned out, even Part 1 (which is the HALFWAY POINT, I should mind) is a big fella! So, hopefully, you guys enjoy this, while I try to put together part 2.

Fenneko: Anyhoo! Let’s see if we can turn back time a wee bit. *starts rewinding footage, to last night, early in the morning* Now, let’s take a looksie at the convenience store we checked out. *finds the cameras for the store, and checks out the footage*

*at around 2:00 AM, the back door flies open, and suddenly a ton of food starts floating out, into the sky…*

Fenneko: …what the fu-

Haida: Look! *he sees other cameras, showing food from all across Tokyo, floating off, in a similar way* What’s going on?!

Fenneko: Actually, look. It’s not all going to the sky, looks like it’s going to that forest over there.

Retsuko: …isn’t that Koajiro Forest?

Haida: …we should probably check it out.

Retsuko: Let’s go! *the two almost take off, before her dress is tugged by something* Huh?

Ikari: Mamaaaa! *whines a little, as an audible growl can come from his stomach*

Retsuko: Aw, Ikari! *pats his head* We’ll get you something to eat soon. Okay, sweetums? *to Fenneko* Can you get him, like, some water, or something, to hold him over?

Fenneko: I can try.

Retsuko: Thanks. *to Haida* Come on!

*the two begin to run off, as the rest of the office is trying to find something resembling food*

Ton: Any luck?!

Komiya: N-no, sir!

Ton: WELL, KEEP LOOKING!

*outside, just on the side of the office building, Retsuko and Haida stand*

Retsuko: *grabbing out a pink microphone, with a heart on top* Ready?

Haida: *revealing his golden belt, with a switch on it* Ready!

*Retsuko twirls the heart on the microphone, and Haida flicks the switch on the belt buckle, as the two do some poses, before shouting out…*

Retsuko and Haida: HENSHIN!

*and with that, they transform, into the adorable, but angry, Pretty-Rage, and the tall, and deadly, Kamen Haida, complete with a motorcycle!*

Kamen Haida: *mounts the motorcycle* Hop on!

Pretty-Rage: *mounts behind him* Let’s figure this out!

Kamen Haida: Right! *drives off, as they head out to Koajiro Forest…*

*meanwhile, in said forest, a gigantic pile of food has been accumulated, by various Byriam foot soldiers (named Cronions), and monitored by two monsters, one being a creature resembling a Kabuki actor, except being considerably obese, named Kuishinbō, and the other being a burnt-red, slim, demonic bird looking being, named Phoenixia*

Kuishinbō: Ohohohohoho! Oh, joyous of days! So much food, ripe for the taking!

Phoenixia: Yes, but this is just the beginning. With all of this, the Earthlings’ energy and morale will be dwindling considerably, giving the empire the perfect time to strike….obviously not the primary concern for you, I imagine.

Kuishinbō: Not at all! *charges at the food pile, and begins chowing down*

*while all this is going down, Pretty-Rage and Kamen Haida are hiding in the bushes, seeing all of this going down*

Kamen Haida: So that’s where it all went.

Pretty-Rage: *getting irritated at the monster eating the food* That bastard…come on! Let’s get them!

Kamen Haida: Right! *the two jump up, causing the Cronions to look around*

Phoenixia: Agh, damn it! They’re here! Get into formation!

*the Cronions prepare themselves, as the two heroes land*

Pretty-Rage: Using my death metal anger to make this a world of happiness! PRETTY-RAGE!

Kamen Haida: A punk at heart trying to bring order to this land! KAMEN HAIDA!

Phoenixia: *sigh* So it appears we meet again.

Pretty-Rage: It appears so, Phoenixia! That food belongs to the civilians of Tokyo! Give it back, now!

Kuishinbō: *jumping up and down* Noooooo! They want to take away my snacks! Cronions! ATTACK!

Cronions: *high pitched squeaks, as they charge towards the two!*

Pretty-Rage: Let’s do this! *jumps up, and screams, causing some Cronions to fall back!*

Kamen Haida: Let’s go! *grabs one goon, and punches it right in the gut, before throwing it aside!*

Phoenixia: Agh! FIRE!

Cronion: *nods, as a few of them grab out uzis, and begin firing at the two heroes!*

Kamen Haida: YIPE! *he and Pretty-Rage jump away from the blast, but when they do, he notices her…squirming* …are you okay?

Pretty-Rage: *clenching her stomach* I-I’m fine! Come on! *runs after the monster*

Kuishinbō: Ohohoho! Feeling a touch weak, are we? Well, maybe this oughta make you feel worse! *grabs out a sword from his side, and slashes her multiple times, causing her to fly back!*

Pretty-Rage: AAAGH! *falls to the ground, unconscious*

Kamen Haida: PRETTY-RAGE! *runs to her, and looks at Kuishinbō* Bastard!

Kuishinbō: Yooooooo!!! *laughs maniacally* I got one! I got one!

Kamen Haida: Ugh! *charges at the monster, and tries to perform a jump-kick*

Kuishinbō: Ohohoho! *grabs Kamen Haida’s foot, and begins swinging him around*

Kamen Haida: What the-?! *gets sent flying to the ground* GAAH! *hits the dirt, next to his knocked-out comrade* Dammit, we’re not up to full strength! I gotta get you out of here! *picks her up* This is not the end! *runs off*

Phoenixia: Oh, it will be. *to some of the Cronion soldiers* YOU! Go after them!

Kamen Haida: *reaching the motorcycle, and drives off, Pretty-Rage carried on his back* Come on, Retsuko, stay with me here! I’ll find some food for you! Someho-*he suddenly hears gunshots* GAH! WHAT THE-?! *he turns, and sees Cronion soldiers, on motorcycles, firing at them* No, NO! *he sees an exit, and immediately makes the turn*

Cronion: *high-pitched scream, as they TRY to make the turn, but crash*

Kamen Haida: Okay…don’t worry, Retsuko. We’ll get you feeling better…*starts feeling dizzy* …no….no, not now…damn it, now I’m getting hungry…and thirsty….and….tired…*suddenly crashes the bike, leaving the two rolling on the ground on the ground, unconscious*

So, um…as you can see, it’s quite the biggun. :P Yeah, I really wanted this to be one big thing, but I wanted to get something out to you guys, so that there’s something to tide everyone over. And as it turned out, even Part 1 (which is the HALFWAY POINT, I should mind) is a big fella! So, hopefully, you guys enjoy this, while I try to put together part 2.

Narrator: Tokyo. A bustling metropolis for the modern age. A prime target for the imperialistic forces of the Byriam Empire, whose goal is to conquer, or destroy, every single being on Earth. But not to fear! For within these city walls lie two of the greatest heroes of our generation! Both are seemingly normal accountants in a boring day job. But secretly, they are the magical red panda of love, Pretty-Rage, and the hyena hero of justice, Kamen Haida! Together, both in battle, and in matrimony, they swore to keep the city safe, and the Byriams at bay. Here they are now, walking with their trusted friend, and tech associate, Fenneko, and their precious son, Ikari, talking about protecting the Earth, no doubt!

Retsuko: Agh, I can’t believe I forgot to pack myself a lunch today! I skipped breakfast too!

Haida: Retsuko, it’s alright! We’ll just quickly walk by some place, and get something for you to eat.

Fenneko: No can do. We’re crunched for time, Ton’s got a lot of work for us.

Haida: …who told y-Tsunoda?

Fenneko: Tsunoda.

Haida: Figured.

Retsuko: Well, there’s a convenience store coming up, you sure we can’t ju-*noticing a fight breaking out in front of the store*

Haida: …come on! *the two run towards the two men fighting*

Customer: *pinning the store clerk to the ground* You son of a bitch! You gonna rob your customers too?!

Store Clerk: I-I’m so sorry! I don’t understand it, myself!

Haida: *pulling the customer back* Hey, HEY! Cool it!

Retsuko: *gets the store clerk back up* What’s going on, here?!

Customer: People are starving out here, that’s what!

Haida: …huh?

Fenneko: *looking inside the store* Uh, guys? I think you might wanna see this.

*they look inside, and see all the food in the convenience store is gone! Not a single morsel left!*

Retsuko: ….what?!

Customer: It’s not just here! The whole town is out of food! Restaurants, lunch rooms, everywhere! I don’t know what kinda strike, or prank this is, but I won’t stand for it! *storms away*

Haida: What the hell…?

Today’s episode: Retsuko’s Starvation! The Gluttonous Monster Attacks!

*later at work…*

Retsuko: *stomach starts growling badly* Why today? WHY?

Fenneko: You know, you give yourself crap for this, but actually, I was gonna make myself something for breakfast, but I couldn’t find anything in my place.

Haida: ….come to think of it, I didn’t see anything in our place too! I know we’re not the richest, but we CAN’T be that broke.

Ton: *distant* WHERE IS MY TEA?!

Tsubone: THERE WAS NONE MADE! WE CHECKED!

Ton: WHAT?! Ugh, *stomping over to check* as if the women in here aren’t lazy enough already! ….wait, where is everything?!

*the other employees begin running towards the tearoom, to discover, like was revealed earlier, there is no consumable object in sight*

Haida: …oh, I hoped that was just an exaggeration.

Fenneko: Okay, something is going on. Come on. *she grabs out her laptop, and places it on the lunch table the three usually sit*

Retsuko: You think it’s the Byriam?

Fenneko: “Think?” Retsuko, I know. We just gotta figure it out. Lucky me, I happened to hack into all the major security cameras in Tokyo.

Haida: ….why?

Fenneko: The less you know, the better. Anyway, it’s apparently been going on all morning, so let’s see if we can figure out what happened last night. *opens up software, to reveal, indeed, security footage spread all across the city* And it looks like the cannibals are out and about this lovely day.

Haida: …we should probably check it out.

Retsuko: Aw, Ikari! *pats his head* We’ll get you something to eat soon. Okay, sweetums? *to Fenneko* Can you get him, like, some water, or something, to hold him over?

Fenneko: I can try.

Retsuko: Thanks. *to Haida* Come on!

*the two begin to run off, as the rest of the office is trying to find something resembling food*

Ton: Any luck?!

Komiya: N-no, sir!

Ton: WELL, KEEP LOOKING!

Retsuko: *grabbing out a pink microphone, with a heart on top* Ready?

Haida: *revealing his golden belt, with a switch on it* Ready!
